sections.text:
A variable can have a short name (like x and y) or a more descriptive name (age, carname, total_volume).
Rules for Python variables:
    ● A variable name must start with a letter or the underscore character
    ● A variable name cannot start with a number
    ● A variable name can only contain alpha-numeric characters and underscores (A-z, 0-9, and _ )
    ● Variable names are case-sensitive (age, Age and AGE are three different variables)
    ● Variable names cannot be the same as Python keywords

sections.subtitle: Example
sections.text:
Legal variable names:
myvar = "John"
_my_var = "John"
myVar = "John"
MYVAR = "John"
myvar2 = "John"

sections.subtitle: Example
sections.text:
Illegal variable names:
2myvar = "John"
my-var = "John"
my var = "John"

Remember that variable names are case-sensitive

sections.subtitle: Multi Words Variable Names
sections.text:
Variable names with more than one word can be difficult to read.
There are several techniques you can use to make them more readable:

sections.subtitle: Camel Case
sections.text:
Each word, except the first, starts with a capital letter:

myVariableName = "John"

sections.subtitle: Pascal Case
sections.text:
Each word starts with a capital letter:

MyVariableName = "John"

sections.subtitle: Snake Case
sections.text:
Each word is separated by an underscore character:

my_variable_name = "John"
